text: [music playing]

ALEX THOMAS: From
obscure teenage prospect

to England's star,
Maro Itoje has come
a long way in a short time.

MARO ITOJE: Three years ago,
I was in my first year of uni,

just my first year in the
senior academy at my club side,
Saracens.
And things were going OK.

But they're going a
little bit better now.

ALEX THOMAS: At just 22,
Itoje has achieved more

with club and country
than many players
do in their entire careers.
He's phenomenal on the field.

And off it, there are three
things that make Maro Itoje
just a little bit different.

He's the middle child of three
born to Nigerian parents.

MARO ITOJE: Both
my mum and my dad

have had huge, huge
impacts on my life.

When I go back to
Nigerians, there's

a lot of Nigerians surprised
at how much of the food I eat,

how much of everything about
Nigeria that I'm aware of.

So I'm still very,
very in-touch with--

well, I'm still
very, very in-touch

and both my siblings are
with our Nigerian roots.

ALEX THOMAS: He's
deeply religious.

MARO ITOJE: I understand that
all my talents or all the gifts
I've been given are from God.

At Saracens, we
actually have a pastor

who comes in once
a week who I've
got a good relationship with.
So they respond to it very well.

ALEX THOMAS: He's
studying politics.

And is puzzled by
Donald Trump's rise.

MARO ITOJE: I scratch
my head a lot.

I don't think I've scratched
my head hard enough.

I think, if I keep on
scratching, I might go bald.

He's-- he's definitely
an interesting guy.

ALEX THOMAS: Maro
Itoje is unique

and he's modest,
but still ambitious.

If your rugby career
came to an end tomorrow,

would you be satisfied with
what you've done or not?
MARO ITOJE: No.
I feel I've got more to give.

And I'm going to
work quite hard to--

very hard to totally
make it happen.
